I've dealt with similar situations, but my parents actually came around when I put my foot down and medically transitioned. Seeing those changes I think aided them in understanding how Important this was to me. I can't say what'll be your journey, but hopefully something will wake her up.

WRITING.TITLE: b'What\xe2\x80\x99s the most well meaning hurtful thing you\xe2\x80\x99ve been told regarding your transness?'
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Possible trigger for misguided transphobia? But it's also a discussion- lemme know if I should change the flair.   Just musing on these things lately looking for camaraderie. It's that special spot between someone's most genuine and most misguided, where it hurts not because it's hateful, but because they mean so well.  The one that sticks with me the most was a coworker/friend who came to me crying after nearly two years of support to tell me that \xe2\x80\x9cGod still saw me as his little girl\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9c God told me that he can't stand you desecrating your body, he still loves you, you don't have to do this to yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d  Again, she was in tears. She felt this with her whole chest. And she meant so well? Can I be angry about it, yeah. Mostly I was just hurt. Just wanted to know if anyone's had similar experiences.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: The consensus is what I'd agree with: Yes, if \xe2\x80\x9cI don't want to date a trans person\xe2\x80\x9d is in the vocabulary, that's transphobic. There are tons of ideas for what being trans looks like, plenty of assumptions and stereotypes, but I know for a fact trans (much like any other defining trait in a person) is a spectrum of identity, presentation, and-  I dunno in my opinion, not the most interesting trait about me? I've got so much other shit going on. We're all so cool, are you kidding me that this is your hang up.   Genital preference imo is a slippery slope. In good faith arguments I can understand it, but if often comes up solely in regards to dating trans people, and once more- there's a lot us. You're really assuming that all of our bits are the same?  Personally I'd rather be just. Glad that I like someone enough to date them, whoever they are, but that's just me. Love is rare, but sure. Narrow the search engine, we don't wanna date someone with these hang ups anyway.   TLDR: Yes and no. It's important to case-by-case when the opinion of \xe2\x80\x9cgenital preference\xe2\x80\x9d comes up, but most people just have a misconception of trans people in general. And if you do- don't worry, we don't wanna date you anyway.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: It's okay to have grief for this self. I certainly do. I dream so often about going back to treatment, to suddenly having that security of \xe2\x80\x9cthe thing that consumes my entire life is the thing I now only have to focus on.\xe2\x80\x9d  It's not that simple anymore. And I can't stand the way my body has changed.   But I also know the journey from body hatred is body neutrality. To ask a challenging thought: what can your body do now that it couldn't before? What are you able to do being a step removed from your eating disorder?  You clearly know what your worst felt like, knowing what it looked like can be really hard. As a last mumble Op, I hear you, I hope you're doing okay. (If not mostly then in this moment, I hope things are easier.)

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Instead of harping on someone clearly in pain and asking her to check herself- let's remember that in almost of our lives our trans experience was defined by the things that hurt us, rather than the innate joy that being trans is.  Like of course there is something to be said about the wording, but you can't tell me that a woman in pain doesn't take precedence over vocabulary.   It took me a very long time to find joy in being trans. It was a journey for years defined mostly by pain and struggle, but I was able to find ways to get comfortable in my body pre-and-post transition. I'm lucky, I redefined my experience with gender euphoria rather than the dysphoria that nearly ended my life.   OP, for a reframe: What if in this life, there is more than this pain? What if through all of this, you are seen as you are, you are able to (if you so choose) to medically transition, what if after all of this you wake up with a comfort and love for who you are?  We can't be sure what's at the end of this life or the next, that much is true. You are a woman. You deserve to be seen as who you are. I see you, I'm sorry things are this bad right now, that matters as much as the possibility that this pain ends. Death isn't a guarantee, it's a full stop. If you want some resources of trans-friendly crisis lines, please feel free to DM.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Hey, that's so exciting! I'm so proud of you for taking this step! I know it can seem scary and overwhelming- and it is- but you are giving yourself the best thing. Years later I will still be chasing the relief that I found in going to treatment for the first time. You deserve this help, and I'm so so proud of you.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Anyone know what that loud noise was? Near Cuba St., kinda sounded like thunder or dumpsters being moved.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Sounds like the force of purging caused your head to hurt. It's scary and a hard reminder that the effects of purging on your body are very real. Please be careful.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Honestly? No. Bodies don't work like that as far as I know. I've never heard of anything like that.   The discomfort you have with your body at a certain weight I hope ends up something you can discuss in therapy. I get it though, I do.  Try not to focus on the distant ahead. Those fears matter, but are for a future you. Ideally, there will be healing both physically and mentally before your body settles into an equilibrium. But take pride in the strengths you're making now. It means you're preparing yourself for future mountains, and you'll be better for it.

WRITING.TITLE: b'I wrote an essay about Disco and the Pale\xe2\x80\xa6'
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Give it a read if you please. Thanks \xe2\x9d\xa4\xef\xb8\x8f  [Hope, Holes in the World, and Disco Elysium](https://medium.com/@dogffish/hope-holes-in-the-world-disco-elysium-180c8c5a032b)

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I'm so sorry that your mother said that to you. That's so hard to hear.   Maybe talk with your dietician about this. I know mine previously opened up a line of communication between my parents and her, which took some of the load off of me. Your professional teams should advocate and speak for you. I strongly recommend talking to your team about it and a.) how to process the remarks and b.) how you felt about it, how to explain your efforts without stepping out of your comfort zone.   I know in my own experience, I never fully went into depth with my parents. They didn't know, no one knew, but I disclosed sometimes the Current aspects of my treatment. (\xe2\x80\x9cI'm working on x meal\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cMy dietician and I are working on x component\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cRight now I'm utilizing y coping strategy to get through x.\xe2\x80\x9d) She's likely looking for physical progress rather than the mental, and I found enlightening my parents to what that looks like helped eased tensions.   This by no means is required, I don't know the relationship you have with your mom, but I hope again you'll talk to your team about the duress this put on you.   You're so strong. I see your effort. It's real. I'm so proud of you. \xe2\x9d\xa4\xef\xb8\x8f

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I was told when my urges come back strong, to \xe2\x80\x9cincrease my support again.\xe2\x80\x9d Be that professional or platonic, online support groups during the day, or what have you.   You aren't getting bad again. This is your ED trying to manifest in intense and uncomfortable ways. You've fought it before and you will again. The fact you didn't use any \xe2\x80\x9ccompensating behaviors\xe2\x80\x9d is huge.   I usually shrink my goalposts when I feel things getting rough.  Celebrate the victories. Take the small things. You also don't know this girl's journey either, maybe she's gone through something similar. Maybe she's been where you've been. It's in moments like these I try to be the kindest I possibly can with myself, because you are worthy of that kindness and love, especially during this time.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Hard agree with the ginger and peppermint. If you're cleared for mild exercise, I find a leisurely walk (10-15 mins max) after a meal helps. Hot water bottles help a lot too, just something warm against the part of you that aches. Slow breathing, distracting activities to keep you busy through the worst of it, it's hard but I promise it's worth it.   Wear clothes with stretchy waistlines, loose fitting fabrics, to welcome your shape. Sweatpants were a godsend to me at this time.   This was the hardest part of treatment for me, believe me I sympathize. You're going through it and you still *are* and that's so amazing in itself.   If it is a comfort, and I'm not sure it is, my own experience with refeeding lead to a slow return to my healthiest weight. I was also still engaging in behaviors at the time. Sending virtual support and love.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: To second what's already been said- yes! It does happen. My time in treatment utterly exhausted me. My ED fought for every scrap it could. That alone left me harrowed.   It takes effort, but recovery leads to the place where there is not exhaustion, but relief. I know that I was on high alert mid-recovery waiting for the other shoe to drop, and trying to understand myself came with an intense exhaustion in itself.   Your body is adjusting, and so is your brain and your you. You're doing the right thing. An electrolyte check can never hurt, but at the very least you're Heard. I'm super super proud of you.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: It's not small and stupid, it's amazing. Each step is a great stride. I'm so so proud of you, friend.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Sometimes sitting in that discomfort is the most powerful thing out there. Think about all the other things you could do if you didn't purge, remember that these little steps, these discomforts, make it easier in the future to detatch/detangle from your ED. Your ED does not have to control you. It can just be this- just sitting with your parent having a nice conversation.   To ease symptoms that make me feel the urge to purge, I usually do a leisurely walk after meals, rely on ginger or peppermint tea, sometimes I really just keep myself rooted to the spot with a wheat bag or hot water bottle.  I actually found a particular video game (Pok\xc3\xa9mon, its Pok\xc3\xa9mon.) keeps me rooted so I can't \xe2\x80\x9cpurge until I finish this level/battle\xe2\x80\x9d and end up staying longer anyways. These are just things that work for me, though.   I do hear you though. That feeling is just awful. But you aren't disgusting. You're human, and that'a wonderful thing to be.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: You've recognized where the issue is. You're heard and seen here, but when you can point out these issues I think these are the most important steps. You know this is a step, leaning toward recovery starts by knowing you would feel stronger/better/happier if you were separate from your ED.   These thoughts can be tamped down with time and redirection. I see you, I hear you, I love you.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Hey, so glad you're reaching out. Tread lightly on forums like these, but I'm so glad you are in her life trying to assist her best.   Here are some basic ED-focused to-avoids. It's not at all extensive and all-encompassing. Everyone has different triggers, but let's do some simple ones:   - be mindful of mentioning \xe2\x80\x9cbad\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cunhealthy\xe2\x80\x9d foods. for one, there's no such thing, for two, it puts an unnecessary stigma on certain types of food choices that someone recovering doesn't really need.  - do not comment on your friend's body. it might be changing, that's okay! that's also good. - try to avoid \xe2\x80\x9cweight talk\xe2\x80\x9d, be it someone's body changing (a friend, a parent trying weight loss, etc) or the time your doctor weighed you. weight is stressful (and does not correlate with your health, BMI is a lie!) and it doesn't need to be blabbed about. it's literally like. the least interesting thing to talk about.  - do not ask direct questions regarding treatment (!!unless your friend brings it up first!!) keep things light unless she invites the conversation. treatment is uncomfortable, it's raw and tiring. if she brings up passing stories, that's cool! things like \xe2\x80\x9cso you're better now?\xe2\x80\x9c or \xe2\x80\x9chow is recovery going?\xe2\x80\x9c can be overwhelming.   and- if you're close enough- ask your friend how you can support her. i think it's particularly hard being asked what you need, but treatment centers do prepare you on average for Knowing things. she might want distracting conversations during meal times. she might want space. she might want someone to talk to, who doesn't hold her with kid gloves. there are easily things that are harder for her to deal with i didn't mention- she might ask to not bring up certain foods or health talk, or even just things that seem weird. she wouldn't ask if it didn't matter.   as a final note, you're a friend, not a counselor. know your boundaries and emotional bandwidth. your friend likely (hopefully) has a team of professionals wiling to talk out the tough stuff. she cares about you too. treat her as you always do, tell her you love her and you support her- give a hug, if she'd like one. take care of yourself first, and the rest can come with it.   best of luck.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I had issues long before I developed an eating disorder. Things started simple with like, guilt around food. I saw my sibling go through some cycle of disordered eating, and my parents commented on their own bodies a lot. While my sister seemed to gotten better since then, I didn't forget it. I have memories around 17-19 binging and purging, yet I still had very\xe2\x80\xa6 I dunno, times when I wasn't focused on my body at all. When I was fine.   When I hit university I went to the gym more often than I ever had. Then I had a professor talk about committing to my values, and I changed my food lifestyle for good. Which exacerbated my long dormant cycle of guilt surrounding food. I kept at it for about 3 years before I sought ED treatment on my own volition.  I only label this all out to say, I was lucky. I didn't have family members commenting on my body. I had peripherally disordered eating habits and mindsets, but I later came into my eating disorder on my own. I wasn't that picky as a kid. Prior to my dietary restrictions, I really had an expansive palate willing to try everything at least once. I'm still gaining that back. I hope I will in time too.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: A great reframe could be: People operating in the world as they are is a moot point that it is okay to exist as we are.   A question to ask ourselves- Is skinny the goal or is it contentment? Is it comfort in our skin?   I think seeing people moving in the world is beautiful, regardless the arbitrary numbers. I hope you are doing better than when you wrote this. I hope venting a little helped.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Yes! You look lovely and I love your piercing!

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: This is likely due to the constant GI upset. Consider the effect that purging has on your stomach. Both ends are going to be affected by this. I've read about people losing the \xe2\x80\x9cgood bacteria\xe2\x80\x9d in your digestive tract and mostly you gotta put something in, be it probiotics via nutrition (yogurt, kombucha, etc) or pills.   I would recommend, tenderly, that if this is something out of your control to seek professional help. Via a doctor's appointment for this singular GI issue, or something more focused on the core problems at hand if you are able to seek any sort of treatment. These side effects really stack up to permanent damage: bone loss, people on here have talked about prolapse and needing surgery, organ failure, heart problems, esophagus deterioration. I'm not saying this to scare you, but I also\xe2\x80\xa6 am? You saying it won't stop you should be frightening to think. I realize EDs really prevent you from thinking rationally, I'm there plenty, but I always benefit from hearing someone else tell me that \xe2\x80\x9chey, that's not normal, that's scary, it should be a red flag.\xe2\x80\x9d  Be very, very careful. These sort of \xe2\x80\x9cside effects\xe2\x80\x9d  is not just on top of your behaviors, it is your body raising alarm bells and crying out for help.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: A huuuge point. Thanks for putting this into words. My thoughts exactly. m

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Had a mild bike accident. Got what my friend called \xe2\x80\x9ccredit-carded\xe2\x80\x9d by the seat, bruised pretty bad for a few days.   It's real. Blunt force can do a number but when it's directly aimed like that the bruising suuucks.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Yea. Still very sensitive down there lol. Not the same but still hurts!

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: If you have anyone who you can stay close to, I think that for me helps a lot. They don't have to know the ins and outs. Having company for a meal, or someone to spend some time with helps in times of crisis.   I'm a big proponent of \xe2\x80\x9cI can't do x behavior until I do y task,\xe2\x80\x9d but the task is something that lasts a long time. Reorganizing your closet, finishing a 10 episode show. The longer I can stay out of the places where I engage in behaviors the better. Easier said than done, I know.   From here, harm reduction imo helps for refocusing. Drink something with electrolytes. Eat soft foods, or nutritionally dense, easy to digest meals. (Soups are my friend when I'm particularly spent, miso soup especially.) Drink water. Drink tea. Don't brush immediately after purging, but do brush your teeth. For some self-love, I recommend nice lotions or a warm shower if that isn't overwhelming.   You're here. You're going to make it. I'm glad you reached out here.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I see you. I'm so glad you're here!

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: You're stronger than your urges. It's good to give yourself nutrients. This isn't about \xe2\x80\x9cbad\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cgood\xe2\x80\x9d food. This is about ensuring you can function through the say. You ate food that you wanted to eat and enjoy, that's not a bad thing!  Try reframing a little. Distractions of company or a fun video might help get through the worst of it. You got this. I'm glad you reached out.   Hang in there.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: First off, two months is HUGE! I'm so proud of you!  I will say what my dietician told me in treatment: Things scream louder when they're dying.   Your ED is seeing your drive and intentional recovery, and that can lead to thinks like symptom swapping (I didn't feel the urge to binge until I kept myself from other behaviors, for instance) or these hard spikes in urges. But behaviors don't mean you haven't been doing the right thing.   Recovery is really really hard. I really feel you on that. But I also know that every time you complete a meal, or mindfully partake, or fend off the urge for five extra minutes or ten or a whole evening- you're beating your ED. It's hold does get less, and these spikes get less frequent.  It's also totally natural to feel these maladaptive coping skills come up with things going on in your life. They've served you in the past, they just don't serve you now. Keep doing what you're doing. Find a new distraction or keep close to someone you trust to ride out the urge wave. You're going to be okay, success or challenge, you're going to make it.

WRITING.TITLE: b'Recovery Takes Everything Out Of Me'
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: When I'm committing to recovery like I have been, I find it takes all my energy and focus, just like my ED does. When I'm deep in my Eating Disorder I can't focus on anything else, but now that I've renewed that determination to get better, I feel like I did in treatment. I can't write or draw. I can't focus or read. I'm too focused on the moment to moment to reach outside of my ED OR my recovery.   I know this is necessary. I know this is the path to getting better (I've done it before, I know it's possible) but that doesn't mean I'm happy with it. When I was in limbo, fighting the ED but allowing it to take up space, I could do other things. Now all my energy is taken up again.   It's a weird double standard. If I want my life back (I do, I do) I have to give it just a little bit more. A bit longer.   I just wanted to know if anyone's felt this too.   For those who need some hope: it gets easier. Step by step, over time. You can still slip up but be in recovery. You can still fall but be in the right path. Eventually these decisions to choose nourishment or joy become second nature, even when sometimes they're hard. It does, it Does get better. It's just hard sometiems too.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: You need nutrition to keep going. I found the shift of \xe2\x80\x9cfood\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cnutrition\xe2\x80\x9d altered my thinking a little bit. I know it's hard. I definitely second something small (I usually suggest something softer on the stomach like soup) and finding someone/something to distract yourself. Watch a movie with someone. Even stay in the same space together, call a friend, watch a youtube video. I also find hot water bottles or heat pads to be really helpful in moments where I'm uncomfortable with the feeling of \xe2\x80\x9cfullness.\xe2\x80\x9d  You got this. And if you slip up, that doesn't mean you're done. That means you can try for next time.   Drink water at least, tea, something with electrolytes. If you can't keep something down you're putting yourself at higher and higher risk for more serious situations (heart failure to low electrolytes, stomach acid burning your throat.) bullimia is one of the highest risk eating disorders. Please drink something. This isn't meant to scare you, but you need to know the risks.   We're here. You got this.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: It's been said already that this is a trait of addiction. It's all encompassing, it's brutal. I don't even talk about it much, if at all, except in specific circles familiar with the struggle, but it still feels like a static film clinging to the rest of me.   To answer the question: I found that separating my ED even by stating \xe2\x80\x9cmy ED does this\xe2\x80\x9d rather than \xe2\x80\x9cI do this\xe2\x80\x9d makes a difference. This is a hard step and something I struggled with, but in treatment it helped me find myself bit by bit again.  You're not your eating disorder, you're affected by it. You struggle with it, but it isn't you. It wants to be, but it can't be. You have interests and hobbies and loves. You have people in your life or music you like. Your ED can be all encompassing, it can take you over, but that's addiction, that's not you.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I'm glad you're safe. I can't imagine how scary that is. I don't know why news stations aren't Iran's current state at the top of their lungs.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Therapy is a great option here. I'd definitely consider looking into it. The feelings that can come up are alarming and confusing, but however you explore your identity (and come back or go forward from that exploration) have meaning.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Proud of you for figuring out what works best for you! Everyone's journey is unique. Medical transition does not change the validity of who you are and how you see yourself. You do not need to conform to the specific societal implications of what it means present a certain way, and you don't need those conventions to fee comfortable in yourself. Wishing you the best!

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Had a coworker just stop talking to me. Wouldn't acknowledge my presence for about 6-7 months. Got to a point where students disrespected me because they mimicked her behavior.   Next year she came by and visited like nothing changed. Joked with me, then quit the next day. Insane.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Yeah no I'm glad it was caught early!! And hopefully it goes well. Dentists freak me out but my fillings went pretty well/seamlessly.   That said, Yeah. I know for me it was this \xe2\x80\x9cI really am doing this to myself huh\xe2\x80\x9d sort of energy. I think it's a good reason to keep in mind or tack onto a list of like \xe2\x80\x9cwhy to commit to recovery\xe2\x80\x9d if that makes sense?  Either way I feel for you. Sending good vibes at least.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Agreed with above, the face swelling if it's occurring at all, is beneficial and necessary.    and uhh, tack on question-  Are there any alternatives to getting electrolytes/potassium/etc other than flavored water or gatorade? I def want it around in the idea of harm reduction (a \xe2\x80\x9cjust in case\xe2\x80\x9d measure) but I hate the taste of gatorade/Powerade.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '

WRITING.TITLE: b' '

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I have yet to hear a compelling argument as to why someone wouldn't date another closer in age. The question you need to ask to the older party (gender irrelevant!) is \xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you not interacting romantically with someone closer to your own age?\xe2\x80\x9d  It never bodes well. Coworkers also screams a power dynamic issue.   25 is barely an adult. The age experience of someone 20 years your senior begs to be put into question. Why are you not attracted to someone older, with similar life experience? What are you looking for when you seek someone 10-15-20 years younger?

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: If you use your phone often, I recommend Recovery Record. Its free and holds a bunch of reminders for meals, lets you personalize with your goals, reasons for recovering, and while some aspects of it feel a bit cheesy (mainly their uplifting phrases you can \xe2\x80\x9ccollect\xe2\x80\x9d) you only have to utilize the parts that work for you.   If you haven't tried online support groups, I find the accountability of even just a time where topics and themes of recovery area being discussed realigns me with my values and Why I want to recovery. If you're in the US there are tons of free online groups.   I definitely get you with this. Recovery is really complicated and I haven't fully committed to Recovery in a long time. But it starts here- with asking how to start. I'm proud of you.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: You can do without. You can achieve something special and plenty fun on your own sober. That's why I've dropped alcohol. You're missing dropped inhibitions and potential dependancies, mostly.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: It is natural for this, to a degree, to feel good. It's a coping mechanism that has been engineered to give us a specific Thing (feelings of control, relief, it varies person to person- and a helpful question to understanding your ED as to What it is giving you, or what it is trying to give you)   I think for me the guilt and pain come after. We know, I feel as though if you're in this r/ you kind of, Know, that this is not good. It is not something to protect us in the long term, and has far more consequences than benefits. We know this, and we still do it, and for me that acknowledgement is where the \xe2\x80\x9cbad\xe2\x80\x9d comes.   Also, let's be honest- purging I would say does not \xe2\x80\x9cfeel\xe2\x80\x9d good. The act thereof kind of sucks, but the after effects come with a boost of brain chemicals. There's science in this, others have pointed it out, addictive properties to the act/ritual/routine that has served a purpose in the past.  TLDR: It feels good not because it \xe2\x80\x9cis\xe2\x80\x9d good, but because this is a disorder that affects and changes your brain chemistry. It is easy to love what is given you, and by proxy what you have to do to get it. It's the definition of addiction.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: When I present masculinely, I see people wary of me. I'm pretty short and slight, but if I'm in my own head just walking (lets be real- a walk home is perfect for brooding on occasion, some somber music, you know) I'll see women cross the street, walk a bit faster or look over their shoulder. I recognize the pattern. I used to do it and I still do.   It's a small thing, not the worst, but I always feel so bad for it. It's one of the first things I noticed as I transitioned. I just wish women felt safer.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I like the advice that everyone has given so far. I'd also suggest reading books with trans characters in them (particularly by trans authors) as experiences vary and implementation varies too. If you're looking for an arc centered around coming out, you've done the right thing by asking for trans narratives outside of what you personally know!  I realize for a while it was dogged on, but the High Guardian Spice anime had one of the most well done trans character arcs I've seen, with a very similar dynamic (trans man mentor, trans woman mentee) that you're talking about.

WRITING.TITLE: b'Little Victories'
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: After a long relapse, I redownloaded RR and am monitoring my food as well as urges. I've been clenching my jaw so much one side of my teeth literally hurts, and no doubt my recent uptick in behaviors have helped my teeth anyways? but I'm back at ground zero. Some 20 hours without behaviors.  I'm posting this *mostly* for myself but also to point out- hey. You can do this. Anyone can do this, and it can start at any point. We're gonna be okay. We can be. I love you all.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Thank you for sharing your story. I really, really like the point here of her missing the relationship between man and woman. It's something I forgot- like people mourn not the change entirely in Our identities, but of their own. (parent's expecting daughters or sons, partners expecting boyfriends/girlfriends, etc) I think for a lot of people that the second \xe2\x80\x9cAlly\xe2\x80\x9d is more direct than \xe2\x80\x9cI know someone who knows someone\xe2\x80\x9d things get a lot more real.  You are right about the grief though. Makes me think.   I know you know your strength, you wouldn't mention so much at the end if you didn't know you survived all of it- but you're a goddamn champion and I'm so glad you're here sharing your story.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I mean, I don't know, but assuming their professional background they're aware of most tricks in the book. Even if you're doing it in a way where you're not engaging in behaviors on site, they're smart. And it's not like they're going to \xe2\x80\x9cpunish\xe2\x80\x9d you for it. If you tell them (or if you don't) they just want information that is going to help them plan the best treatment for you possible. Recovery looks different for everyone, it's all highly individualized.  And to note, most professionals in this field I've found have an experience with it directly. They've been where you've been, where you are, I mean. They kinda know how sneaking around works.   Like, to emphasize, it's scary! And it's natural to want to cling to something familiar that has gotten you through so much. But you're gonna come out the other side of this with more tools to equip on times of crisis. Some of part of us, always, wants to live.  TLDR: Come/go as you are. These are people determined to see you through, who want you to be okay. And hey, I'm proud of you.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Ugh, that's so dire. It all sucks. What I'm trying to do right is recenter with not \xe2\x80\x9cchallenges\xe2\x80\x9d and make the point of like, complete meal, distract until next meal. Baby steps in the direction of recovery are the point of  recovery, yeah? Sometimes we gotta start from point one again.   But I sympathize. Currently it's not, and I'm not sure when it will be, but I'm logging back into online support groups, which will be nice. I def recommend those to anyone who has the availability for them.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: No worries my guy! Take your time and however you go, I hope it's a positive experience nevertheless!

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I went through PP. Very kind. Well meaning, genuinely such a great experience. Two trips and I had my vial. I will say that they are *extremely* hard to get a hold of in some areas, so while you can certainly get the prescription through them I would try to get involved with another practice once you get established. Been on T for 5 years and I still have to pull teeth to get that prescription renewed (often in person appointments that I called for 3 weeks to get an answer, any answer. Leaving a message leads me nowhere.) There are two PPs in my immediate area and both are like this. Just a lot of demand and not enough support. And doctors in my area were super transphobic and unwilling, they were my only lifeline which I am grateful for- but they do do this unfortunately.  TLDR: More doctors will be more comfortable prescribing HRT after you get established to the best of my knowledge. PP has Informed Consent to make the route to medical transition possible, but they are hard to get a hold of in some areas. Best of luck!!

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: As someone who did this in treatment- it comes back to bite you. Professionals know when you're still engaging in behaviors, even if they don't say anything.  I'm not going to say that Treatment Will Change You, treatment was one of the hardest things I've ever done, but it does show you how to rewire that circuit in your brain that needs that control. It helps. The first day I didn't exhibit any symptoms, the first week? It's a freedom and a *control* I thought I'd never see again.   Hoping the best for you. You got this.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I'm feeling this pretty hard. I feel like I don't have any safe foods anymore. I'm almost a year out of a day treatment and sometimes these last couple weeks I've felt the walls closing in. No matter what I eat, new or old or familiar of desired, even if I want the food I feel the urges come back strong.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: For me, it's a sludge. It dulls the colors of the world. It leadens my muscles. It makes things hard to do- to move my head, to focus, to get out of bed. I'm fairly high functioning with medication, can laugh and can't cry, but I still often feel just Heavy. Weighed down with it.  Other times it's just. I dunno. A tremendous guilt, an insensitive, harsh critic drowning out all other noise. It's still heavy though, makes me feel hollow but absolutely made of stone. Foggy days are frequent too, but that's any number of factors.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: If therapy doesn't help, you're not into it or you're with the wrong therapist. Multiple types of therapy exist, and it doesn't have to be 1x1, there's group therapy, there's support groups in general.  As a note, I wasn't able to get gender therapy. US medical insurance system, amirite?  This isn't me saying you have to go, and I'm sorry your parents are asking such invasive questions, but to prescribe to some good faith therapy is helpful for Plenty of things outside of gender. Just, consider why you're against it, or if you'd respond differently against the question if anyone else asked. (Aaand if I'm off the mark here and this was more Gender Therapy focused forgive me (heart emoticon))

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: It's real. I didn't think I could be in love and I am now, travelled to a completely different country and couldn't be happier because I know despite the many terrifying things in the world we'll make it. We buy each other lunch. We plan little dates. We go out and spend time together or stay in and cook something nice. It ebbs and flows, but it's always here.   This world is scary but by god I will carve out a corner filled up with the things I love. It's real.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: How many adults aren't. They're petty and dance around hard topics and getting straight answers from people can be really difficult. WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: That's tough. I will say that any process of medical transition can and Will cause doubts and concerns. After surgery people often talk about how there's a guilt to \xe2\x80\x9cputting your body through this.\xe2\x80\x9d I will say for a lot (if not most) that concern passes after a while. Doesn't mean this isn't real, or hard.   Honestly it depends on your comfort with yourself. I come to this crossroads a lot lately myself, and I usually stick with \xe2\x80\x9cconsistent but low levels of prescribed hormone,\xe2\x80\x9d but that's just what works for me.   Maybe you want essentially a \xe2\x80\x9cmaintenance dose.\xe2\x80\x9d That said, 3 months in means there's a Lot of changes that still need to go underway before you're at equilibrium.  If you're concerned about sperm production, maybe look into sperm donor banks? I know some can freeze/analyze your sperm count, but bio-straps are not my area of expertise. Definitely touch base with them, but if it is any comfort 3 months of HRT shouldn't blast your sperm count. Not that intensely.   Bottom line, you're a woman. You're going to be a woman with or without medical transition. You're gonna be okay.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Yes, but *straps.* Whatever your poison I think there's something for everyone.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I would also question an aversion to trans people. The reasons speak to validity, but I know I felt a certain way for a long time and then flipped because, I don't want to have to explain my Transgender Existence to a cis person. I don't think cis people can understand the nuances of trans people (especially anyone outside of the binary) and I've gotten tired of feeling like I need to justify myself to cis folks. (Not a cis-bash, just stating opinions here.)  But I digress. Attraction is attraction, but I'd also ask myself what about someone's gender journey strikes a dull chord. (Why do I want to forget my trans identity, why is it that trans experiences drain me, do I not want to validate another trans person's experience? do I feel that a cis person has to validate my experience- why? what is it in myself that I don't want to see reflected in another trans person?) Those sorts of things. That doesn't mean break up with your partner or w/e, find who makes you warm and keep em close! And by no means am I attempting to be accusatory. These are questions I have asked myself. I just always, always question those thoughts when they came up. I dunno about you but I was raised pretty hardcore in gender roles. Lotta research, lot of growth.   That said about T- yeah. T gave me a weird relationship with sex, I definitely struggle with it a lot. You're not alone there. If ace is the shoe that fits by all means use it. Sex-neutrality or sex-positive ace folks also exist, so welcome if that feels your vibe!

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Yeah, nah. I couldn't. I've been there and done that. When people hit this point I personally have come to the conclusion that I don't need to \xe2\x80\x9cchange them,\xe2\x80\x9d and more importantly it is Their job to do the work and research to figuring out their shit.   If you want to be direct, a text stating your feelings and why you don't want to spend time with someone invalidating your entire experience. You *could* give them a chance and point out your history together, or you could just state how you feel and close that door.   I'm personally a painful \xe2\x80\x9cI'm antsy if a door is left open so I slam it on my way out\xe2\x80\x9d but that is not the way you have to live your life.   For what it's worth: I'm sorry. You are exactly who you are, and that demands worth and respect. Tread light.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Here's the cool thing about sexuality- it's whatever you like. It's fluid. It can lean one way or another and the labels that feel comfortable to you are the ones that you should use. If that's straight or \xe2\x80\x9cheteroflexible\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cI dunno, people are cute\xe2\x80\x9d that's fine too.  As a reminder, liking men who are \xe2\x80\x9cfeminine\xe2\x80\x9d is still liking men. Maybe you just have a type. I just know \xe2\x80\x9cfemboys\xe2\x80\x9d can be a bit of a charged term in some circles. You're by all means allowed to find them attractive, but not everyone people consider a femboy calls themselves one, y'know?  You can experiment too. Even if you just poke around in online circles calling yourself bisexual or pansexual, or straight! You are under no obligation to have yourself figured out. I have yet to meet someone who does.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: It's normal! We notice when people are attractive (through societal standards, but beauty conventions is a whole conversation) it's perfectly normal. You are perfectly fine looking at attractive people and telling them they're attractive. Guys don't hype each other up enough.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Friend, you have survived a tremendous amount. You do not have to feel selfish or guilty. Any mental health issue is sometimes like operating with blinders. Anxiety makes it hard for me to see logical solutions, or overthink the simple. Brains are fickle, tricky things.  There are many things that a sick brain tells us, so many of them are lies. You aren't foolish or guilty, you didn't know. You could not have seen the answes around you given your situation. People who cared for you showed up when you needed them. You don't *owe* them anything, you are here. For them, clearly, that is enough.  As someone who had survived a number of paltry attempts, much without the knowledge of my loved ones, it's okay. It's okay, and I'm so glad you had people to support you through the aftermath. (Because regardless or not the intent an accident like that IS trauma, attempts ARE trauma. You are a damn champion for writing this out.)  Happy you're sticking around longer. There's a lot in this world to look forward to. And that's where you are- forward! Learning as you go, leaving the past behind to carve a better future.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Agreed with the most of the ppl here. If you're part of the club, feel free to rib/etc, if not- their intonation to the comment speaks a lot to get off of. (Are they anticipating a response, is it spoken neutrally/warmly/negatively, is it a one off comment or a topic they wish to discuss?) Mostly, I mind my own. This is one of those topics I believe that if you're not in the same club, it's time to take a backseat and listen.   Given the situation, you could also ask what they need. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you want support or an ear?\xe2\x80\x9d If it's just a one off, let them define themselves how they see fit. If that's the word they use out of self-love. Sure. Hype em' up. everyone's body is their own business. I don't ever think that it's really appropriate to comment on someone's body.  \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I love you\xe2\x80\x9d is not always the take (you don't love them \xe2\x80\x9cin spite\xe2\x80\x9d of their fatness, do you? Then maybe it's not appropriate.)

Admitting this is new is not bad or scary. Most people I know are into their twenties and haven't gone on a date. You got this dude. So excited for you.

Jesus Jesus by Noah Gundersen. WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: You go on. It's the only way. Center your belief in the notion that you are worthy (even if worth is something you struggle with, because everyone struggles with it) of something else, something more, and you go on. Slowly, surely, step by step. Forgiveness doesn't come easy, but (I believe, I hope) comes eventually. You don't need to forgive yourself to start healing. In my experience, you start healing to someday forgive yourself.   I love you. I hope you're okay.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: hey there! i'm a nonbinary student. i transferred here last year and my experience has been well enough. for starters gender inclusive housing is available, and in certain halls (the new jennings hall for instance) bathrooms are self-enclosed so you don't have to worry about indecent exposure. in the dorming portals there is no way to indicate if someone will be open to rooming with lgbtq+ students, so that for me was trial and error. i eventually DID find a roommate and we get along extraordinarily well, but if you'd rather have a room by yourself or with someone better aligned to your identity- that's something especially available as of recent.   on the application, they changed \xe2\x80\x9cgender\xe2\x80\x9d back to one's \xe2\x80\x9csex\xe2\x80\x9d for students. which is sort of a backstep imo. there's effort, but it often can come off as well-intended but poorly executed.  there are clubs around: Shades of Pride, QUEST, SOGIE, Madison Equality are all readily available and wonderful. However, in my experiences in my major of study I'm entirely outnumbered by cis people. the campus is primarily white, a little overwhelmingly so, and often not intentionally bigoted, but ignorant. i've had issues of transphobia with students (never with professors, though) and i do not feel comfortable outing myself in most circles. simply put from my own experience: the staff try, if they know. the student body themselves are not one i put a lot of faith in.   due to my own introversion and discombobulated state (mostly due to the college atmosphere in general) i didn't spend a lot of time in the aforementioned clubs, but i can tell you the time i spent there was valuable. i believe places like shades of pride and QUEST and all of the above are entirely necessary. they're open and welcoming and the counseling center has also been warm to lgbtq+ students.  through my own wariness of the College Experience, i'll say tread lightly. there are some incredible staff members dedicating to helping (the associate dean of admissions, joe, comes to mind. he was so helpful for me moving forward, as well as jennifer iwerks who helps run SOGIE.) but you really have to find your niche. i wouldn't call jmu a diverse community, and certainly not a wildly liberal college overall, but there are people in the right places. you simply have to work to find them.   hope this helps. :-)
